channel.title: Amazon EMR Release Notes
channel.description: A RSS feed containing the latest updates on https://docs.aws.amazon.com/emr/latest/ReleaseGuide/.

item.title: Release 7.9.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.9.0 contains application upgrades such as Hadoop 3.4.1 and Zookeeper 3.9.3. This version includes CM-CMK support for Persistent App UI and support for launching EMR clusters on the FIPS enabled AL2023 AMI. See the 7.9.0 release notes for more information.

item.title: Release 7.8.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.8.0 contains application upgrades such as Apache Iceberg 1.7.1-amzn-1 and Delta 3.3.0-amzn-0 and Zookeeper 3.9.3.

item.title: Release 7.7.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.7.0 contains application upgrades such as Apache Iceberg 1.7.1-amzn-0 and Delta 3.2.1-amzn-2 and Trino 467.

item.title: Release 7.6.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.6.0 contains application upgrades such as HBase 2.6.1, Flink 1.20.0, Spark 3.5.3, and Trino 457. The release also includes Amazon S3 client-side encryption for the S3A filesystem connector and TLS support on HMaster and RegionServer endpoints.

item.title: Release 7.5.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.5.0 contains application upgrades such as Delta 3.2.1-amzn-0, HBase 2.5.10, Hudi 0.15.0-amzn-2, and Iceberg 1.6.1-amzn-1. The release also includes EMR write-ahead logs (WAL) support for cross cluster replication.

item.title: Release 7.4.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.4.0 contains application upgrades such as AWS SDK for Java 2.28.8, Delta 3.2.0-amzn-1, Flink 1.19.1, Hadoop 3.4.0, HBase 2.5.5, Hudi 0.15.0-amzn-1, Iceberg 1.6.1-amzn-0, Phoenix 5.2.0, Presto 0.287, Spark 3.5.2, Trino 446, and Zookeeper 3.9.2. Features include the Yarn ResourceManager providing graceful decommissioning for files served by the Spark external shuffle service.

item.title: Release 7.3.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.3.0 contains application upgrades such as Delta 3.2.0-amzn-0, Hudi 0.15.0-amzn-0, Iceberg 1.5.2-amzn-0, TensorFlow 2.16.1, Trino 442, and Zeppelin 11.1.

item.title: Release 7.2.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.2.0 contains application upgrades such as Apache Iceberg 1.5.0-amzn-0 and Delta 3.1.0. This release also adds suppor so that you can use other applications such as HBase, Flink, and Hive with the Amazon S3 Express One Zone storage class.

item.title: Release 5.36.2 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 5.36.2 contains important fixes and improvements.

item.title: Release 7.1.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.1.0 contains important upgrades and fixes, including an upgrade of Livy to 0.8.0 and ZooKeeper to 3.9.1. Amazon EMR 7.1 also adds several features, such as integrating Apache Livy as an endpoint for your Amazon EKS cluster and EMR Serverless applications. This release also adds support for Lake Formation with Amazon EMR on EKS, so you can manage and secure data lakes with fine-grained access control.

item.title: Release 7.0.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 7.0.0 contains important upgrades and fixes, including an upgrade of Apache Spark to version 3.5.0. Amazon EMR 7.0 adds support for the Amazon CloudWatch agent application, and removes support for Ganglia. This release also makes Amazon Corretto 17 the default JDK for applications that support JDK17, and changes all EMR clusters to run on AL2023 by default.

item.title: Release 6.15.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 6.15.0 contains important upgrades and fixes, including an upgrade of Apache Hadoop to version 3.3.6, migration of the AWS SDK to v2, asynchronous split opening capability for Tez, general availability of Apache Flink support on Amazon EMR on EKS clusters, and mutual-TLS encrypted communication between workers in your EMR Serverless Spark job runs.

item.title: Release 6.14.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 6.14.0 contains important upgrades and fixes, including improvements to cluster scaling operations and Amazon EMR log management, and the general availability of managed scaling in the Asia Pacific (Jakarta) (ap-southeast-3) Region.

item.title: Release 6.13.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 6.13.0 contains important upgrades, improvements, and fixes, including improvements to the Amazon EMR log management daemon to ensure that all logs are uploaded at a regular cadence to Amazon S3 when a cluster termination command is issued, and timely upload of all log files to Amazon S3 for long-running EMR clusters.

item.title: Releases 6.11.1, 6.10.1, 6.9.1, and 6.8.1 now available
item.description: These Amazon EMR patch releases include important security and performance updates. We recommend that you use the latest patch release for the most recent release version that works with your processes.

item.title: Release 6.12.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 6.12.0 supports all applications with Amazon Corretto 8 by default, except for Trino. For Trino, Amazon EMR 6.12.0 uses Amazon Corretto 17 by default. Amazon EMR also supports some applications with Amazon Corretto 11 and 17. Amazon EMR 6.12 includes Java 11 runtime support for Flink. With 6.12, you can also use the LDAP over SSL (LDAPS) protocol to launch a cluster that natively integrates with your corporate identity server.

item.title: Release 6.11.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 6.11.0 includes improvements to the DynamoDB connector, and fixes an issue related to using Delta Lake to store Delta table data in Amazon S3 after column rename operation. 6.11 also fixes an issue with using edge nodes on clusters with multiple primary nodes, and improves the automation process used to re-mount Amazon EBS volumes to an instance after a reboot.

item.title: Release 5.36.1 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 5.36.1 adds support for archiving logs to Amazon S3 during cluster scale-down, improves the on-cluster log management daemon, and fixes an issue where an Amazon EC2 hardware failure on one of the primary nodes could cause a second primary node to fail and render your cluster unstable.

item.title: Release 6.10.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 6.10.0 includes a native Trino-Hudi connector that provides read access to data in Hudi tables. Amazon EMR 6.10.0 automatically adds the required spark-redshift related jars to the executor class path for Spark. 6.10.0 also includes improvements to the on-cluster log management daemon that minimize disk over-utilization. This release also supports regional endpoints for EMRFS user mapping.

item.title: Release 6.9.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 6.9.0 includes a new open-source application, Delta Lake. The Amazon Redshift integration for Apache Spark is included in this release. 6.9.0 adds support for archiving logs to Amazon S3 during cluster scale-down. You can now use Apache Flink on Amazon EMR for unified BATCH and STREAM processing of Apache Hive Tables or metadata of any Flink tablesource such as Iceberg, Kinesis or Kafka. You can now specify IAM runtime roles and AWS Lake Formation-based access control for Apache Spark, Apache Hive, and Presto queries on Amazon EMR on EC2 clusters with Amazon SageMaker Runtime Studio.

item.title: Release 6.8.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR release 6.8.0 comes with Apache HBase release 2.4.12, which lets you both archive and delete your HBase tables so you can skip the archive process and quickly drop and delete large tables. The Amazon EMR steps feature now supports Apache Livy endpoint and JSBC/ODBC clients. Amazon EMR 6.8.0 comes with Apache Spark 3.3.0, which uses Apache Log4j 2 and the log4j2.properties file to configure Log4j in Spark processes. You must migrate to the new spark-log4j2 configuration classification and key format for Apache Log4j 2 before upgrading to 6.8.0. Amazon EMR 6.8.0 comes with Apache Hudi 0.11.1; however, Amazon EMR 6.8.0 clusters are also compatible with the open source hudi-spark3.3-bundle_2.12 from Hudi 0.12.0. This release also fixes an issue that causes a NoSuchMethodError when Amazon EMR reads Apache Phoenix tables through the Apache Spark shell.

item.title: Release 6.7.0 now available
item.description: Amazon EMR now supports Apache Spark 3.2.1, Apache Hive 3.1.3, HUDI 0.11, PrestoDB 0.272, and Trino 0.378. Also supports IAM Role and Lake Formation-based access controls with EMR Steps (Spark, Hive) for Amazon EMR on EC2 clusters. Supports Apache Spark data definition statements on Apache Ranger enabled clusters. This now includes support for Trino applications reading and writing Apache Hive metadata on Apache Ranger enabled clusters. For more information, see Enable federated governance using Trino and Apache Ranger on Amazon EMR.

item.title: Release 6.6.0 now available
item.description: Support for Apache Spark 3.2, Apache Spark RAPIDS 22.02, CUDA 11, Apache Hudi 0.10.1, Apache Iceberg 0.13, Trino 0.367 and PrestoDB 0.267. New Amazon EMR clusters with the default Amazon Linux (AL) AMI option automatically use the latest Amazon Linux AMI. Applications that use Log4j 1.x and Log4j 2.x are upgraded to use Log4j 1.2.17 (or higher) and Log4j 2.17.1 (or higher) respectively, without the need for a bootstrap action. Improved cluster startup time.

item.title: Release 6.5.0 now available
item.description: Support for Apache Iceberg open table format for huge analytic datasets. Also, support for Ranger Trino plugin version 2.0.1-amzn-1.

item.title: Release 6.4.0 now available
item.description: New Hudi features and improvements, including Hudi now supports Optimistic Concurrency Control (OCC). Hive features and performance improvements, including query compilation time reduced by 2.5 times with Glue metastore Partition Pruning.

item.title: Release 6.3.0 now available
item.description: With Amazon EMR 6.3.0, you can launch a cluster that natively integrates with Apache Ranger. Apache Ranger is an open-source framework to enable, monitor, and manage comprehensive data security across the Hadoop platform. For more information, see Apache Ranger. With native integration, you can bring your own Apache Ranger to enforce fine-grained data access control on Amazon EMR. See Integrate Amazon EMR with Apache Ranger in the Amazon EMR Management Guide.

item.title: Release 5.33.0 now available
item.description: With Amazon EMR 5.33.0, Amazon EMR supports Amazon S3 Access Points, a feature of Amazon S3 that allows you to easily manage access for shared data lakes.

item.title: Release 5.32.0 now available
item.description: Beginning with Amazon EMR 5.32.0, you can launch a cluster that natively integrates with Apache Ranger. Apache Ranger is an open-source framework to enable, monitor, and manage comprehensive data security across the Hadoop platform. For more information, see Apache Ranger. With native integration, you can bring your own Apache Ranger to enforce fine-grained data access control on Amazon EMR. See Integrate Amazon EMR with Apache Ranger in the Amazon EMR Release Guide.

item.title: Release 6.2.0 now available
item.description: With Amazon EMR 6.2.0, you can launch a cluster that integrates with Lake Formation. This integration provides fine-grained, column-level data filtering to databases and tables in the AWS Glue Data Catalog It also enables federated single sign-on to EMR Notebooks or Apache Zeppelin from an enterprise identity system. For more information, see Integrating Amazon EMR with Lake Formation.

item.title: Release 5.31.0 now available
item.description: With Amazon EMR 5.31.0, you can launch a cluster that integrates with Lake Formation. This integration provides fine-grained, column-level data filtering to databases and tables in the AWS Glue Data Catalog. It also enables federated single sign-on to EMR Notebooks or Apache Zeppelin from an enterprise identity system. For more information, see Integrating Amazon EMR with Lake Formation.

item.title: Release 6.1.0 now available
item.description: PrestoSQL 338 support with JDK-11 and Spark 3.0. Support for Hive ACID transactional tables. Simplified ECR integration with Docker container.

item.title: Release 5.30.1 now available
item.description: Bug fixes and the availability of persistent off-cluster YARN application server history and Tez UI.

item.title: EMR notebooks run kernels on cluster with 5.30.0 and later
item.description: Running kernels on cluster with EMR 5.30.0 and later improves notebook performance and allows you to install and customize kernels. You can also install Python libraries on the cluster master node.

item.title: Release 5.30.0 now available
item.description: EMR 5.30.0 now supports Amazon Linux 2, and Presto Auto Scale with Graceful Decommission. Upgraded versions of Flink, Ganglia, Hbase, Hudi, Hue, JupyterHub, Livy, Oozie, Presto, AWS SDK for Java, AWS Glue connector, Amazon SageMaker Spark SDK, Amazon Kinesis connector, EMR Record Server, EMR DynamoDB Connector.

item.title: Release 6.0.0 now available
item.description: EMR 6 now supports Hadoop 3. Amazon Linux 2 is the operating system and Coretto JDK 8 is the default JDK for EMR 6. Spark can run in the context of a Docker container. Hive now supports the LLAP execution mode. Upgraded versions of Hive, HBase, Phoenix, Presto, Zeppelin, AWS SDK for Java.

item.title: Release 5.29.0 now available
item.description: Spark performance optimizations. Upgraded versions of MariaDB Connector and Amazon Redshift JDBC Driver.

item.title: Release 5.28.1 now available
item.description: Fixed Spark compatibility issues. Fixed Amazon CloudWatch Metrics publishing on an EMR cluster with multiple master nodes. Disabled false Apache version log message.

item.title: Release 5.28.0 now available
item.description: Support added for Hudi (Incubating). Expanded application support for multiple master node clusters. Upgraded versions of Hive, Zeppelin, Flink, Phoenix, MXNet, and Presto.

item.title: Release 5.27.0 now available
item.description: Upgraded versions of Spark, Presto, Flink, JupyterHub, TensorFlow, EMR DynamoDB Connector, and AWS SDK for Java.

item.title: EMR block public access and Notebook-scoped libraries for EMR notebooks now available
item.description: Configure EMR Block public access prevents clusters from launching when a security group allows public access. Install your own Notebook-scoped Python libraries within the notebook editor in addition to cluster libraries and isolated to the current session.

item.title: Release 5.26.0 now available
item.description: Upgraded versions of HBase, Phoenix, AWS SDK for Java, and connectors and drivers. Improved Spark performance.

item.title: Local disk encryption and S3 encryption improvements
item.description: Now configure Amazon S3 encryption and local disk encryption independently. With release 5.24.0 and later, use EBS encryption for local disks to encrypt the root device volume and local storage volumes.

item.title: Release 5.25.0 now available
item.description: Upgraded versions of Hive, Presto, Spark, TensorFlow, Tez, Zookeeper, and AWS SDK for Java. Improved Spark performance.

item.title: Release 5.24.0 now available
item.description: Upgraded versions of Spark, Flink, Presto, Livy, Hue, JupyterHub, MxNet, DynamoDB Connector, MariaDB Connector, Amazon Redshift JDBC Driver, and AWS SDK for Java. Improved Spark performance.

item.title: Support for EMR Cluster with multiple master nodes now available
item.description: With Amazon EMR 5.23.0 and later, you can launch a cluster with three master nodes to support high availability of applications like YARN Resource Manager, HDFS Name Node, Spark, Hive, and Ganglia. The master node is no longer a potential single point of failure with this feature. If one of the master nodes fails, Amazon EMR automatically fails over to a standby master node and replaces the failed master node with a new one with the same configuration and bootstrap actions.

item.title: Configuring applications in a running cluster now available
item.description: With Amazon EMR version 5.21.0 and later, you can override cluster configurations and specify additional configuration classifications for each instance group in a running cluster. You do this by using the Amazon EMR console, the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI), or the AWS SDK. For more information, see Supplying a Configuration for an Instance Group in a Running Cluster.

item.title: Release 5.23.0 now available
item.description: Upgraded version of AWS SDK for Java.

item.title: Release 5.22.0 now available
item.description: Increased default storage for EBS-only instance types, new property to tune Spark performance, and upgraded versions of Flink, HBase, Oozie, Phoenix, and Zeppelin.

item.title: Release 5.20.0 now available
item.description: Upgraded versions of Flink and Presto.

item.title: Kerberos now supports external KDCs
item.description: Kerberos in Amazon EMR now supports authenticating principals from an external KDC. This centralizes principal management because multiple clusters can share a single, external KDC. In addition, the external KDC can have a cross-realm trust with an Active Directory domain. This allows all clusters to authenticate principals from Active Directory.

item.title: Release 5.20.0 now available
item.description: Upgraded versions of Flink, HBase, Hadoop, Hive, Hue, MxNet, Presto, Spark, Tensorflow, and Tez.

item.title: EMR Notebooks now available
item.description: EMR Notebooks is a managed environment based on Jupyter Notebook now available with clusters created using EMR release version 5.18.0 and later. It supports kernels for PySpark, Spark SQL, Spark R, and Scala.

item.title: Release 5.19.0 now available
item.description: Improved performance of Spark writes to S3 with the S3 optimized committer. Upgraded versions of Hadoop, Flink, JupyterHub, MXNet, Presto, TensorFlow, and Zookeeper.

item.title: Release 5.18.0 now available
item.description: New artifact repository in Maven helps you check dependencies in your job code before you deploy. S3 Select support added for Presto and Hive. Upgraded versions of Flink, HBase, Presto, Spark, and Zeppelin.

item.title: Release 5.17.0 now available
item.description: TensorFlow now available. New support for S3 Select in Spark and S3 persistence for Jupyter notebooks. Upgraded versions of Flink, HBase, and Presto.

item.title: Release 5.16.0 now available
item.description: Upgraded versions of Hadoop, Flink, Livy, MXNet, Phoenix, Presto, and Spark. Changes to support LDAP authentication with Spark.

item.title: Release 5.15.0 now available
item.description: Upgraded versions of HBase, Hive, Hue, Oozie, Zookeeper. Kerberos in EMR now supports Livy.
